title: Tropical Storm Heads for Puerto Rico
text:
A newly formed tropical storm in the Atlantic could hit Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands early this week while dumping as much as half a foot of rain, according to the National Hurricane Center.

Tropical Storm Karen formed in the Windward Islands north of Venezuela and is forecast to head west-northwest before turning north, the Hurricane Center said Sunday. The Center added tropical storm watches for Puerto Rico and both the British and U.S. Virgin Islands, saying they could be hit Tuesday with heavy rain, flash flooding and tropical-storm-force winds.

The Windward Islands are forecast to get as much as 8 inches of rain, while up to 6 inches could hit parts of Puerto Rico and the Virgin islands. The forecast for Karen didn’t extend far enough out to show if it will eventually threaten the U.S. mainland. The Hurricane Center doesn’t expect the storm to strengthen in the next two days. Karen formed during a busy time for extreme weather in the Atlantic. Jerry, another tropical storm to the north, could brush by Bermuda early this week as it heads northeast. Meanwhile, the Hurricane Center said there was a 90% chance that a disturbance off West Africa could become a tropical cyclone within 48 hours. Write to Jon Kamp at jon.kamp@wsj.com
